description.en:
Personal boundaries are psychological, emotional, and physical limits we set to protect our well-being and self-respect. Healthy boundaries allow us to say 'no', defend our needs, and not live for others' expectations. People-pleasing is a behavior pattern where a person systematically sacrifices their interests for others' approval, fearing conflict and rejection.

Lack of healthy boundaries leads to emotional burnout, accumulated resentment, loss of self, and toxic relationships. People with blurred boundaries often feel used, cannot refuse, and live a life based on others' expectations rather than their own values.

This test is based on research in assertiveness, codependency, and attachment theory. It measures six key aspects: ability to say 'no', prioritizing one's needs, emotional autonomy, tendency to please, fear of rejection, and clarity of personal boundaries. Results will help you understand where your boundaries need strengthening and provide practical recommendations.

test_metadata.author: Based on boundaries and assertiveness research

target_audience.en: Adults 18+, especially those who struggle with saying no and defending their interests

en: Never
Rarely
Sometimes
Often
Always

description.en: Ability to openly express thoughts, feelings, and needs, say 'no' without guilt
Caring for one's needs, ability to put oneself first without feeling selfish
Independence from others' opinions, ability to maintain self and not merge emotionally
Behavior pattern where one sacrifices oneself for approval and conflict avoidance
Anxiety that defending boundaries will lead to loss of relationships or approval
Understanding of personal limits, what is acceptable and unacceptable in relationships

text.en: I can say 'no' to a request if it's inconvenient for me
I find it hard to refuse people even when I'm overloaded
I openly express disagreement when something doesn't suit me
I say 'yes' when I want to say 'no' to avoid conflict
I calmly defend my point of view without fearing others' reactions
I find it difficult to tell someone their behavior hurts me
I can set clear rules in relationships without feeling guilty
I avoid expressing my needs directly
I dedicate time to my interests and hobbies even if others ask for help
I feel guilty when I take care of myself instead of others
My own needs are as important as others' needs
I put others' needs above my own
I can cancel a meeting if I feel tired or need to be alone
I think it's selfish to refuse help for the sake of my rest
I invest in my health and well-being even if it requires time
I ignore my needs for others' comfort
My self-esteem doesn't depend on others' opinions
Others' criticism strongly affects my mood and self-perception
I can maintain my opinion even if everyone around thinks differently
I feel responsible for other people's emotions
I can make decisions based on my values, not others' expectations
I easily absorb others' moods and lose myself
I feel like a whole person, independent of relationships
My happiness depends on loved ones' approval
I do things I don't want to just to be liked
I agree with the majority even if I think differently
I apologize excessively even when not at fault
I hide my true feelings to not upset others
I take on tasks I don't want to do to not let others down
I sacrifice my time for others even when it's inconvenient
I change my behavior depending on who's around
I find it hard to disappoint someone even if it's fair
I fear people will turn away if I refuse them
The thought that someone might be angry at me causes strong anxiety
I avoid conflicts at any cost, even to my detriment
I panic at the thought that someone might not like me
I'm willing to change myself just to be accepted
I feel devastated after any conflict
I need constant confirmation that I'm loved and valued
I fear being alone if I'm too demanding
I know exactly what is acceptable and what isn't in relationships
I find it hard to tell when someone crosses my boundaries
I have clear rules regarding my time and space
I'm not sure where I end and another person begins
I can easily explain my personal boundaries to others
I find it hard to understand what I feel and want
I know my limits and don't let others violate them
Boundaries are a vague concept to me, I don't understand where they should be

overall_boundary_health.note: Inverts people_pleasing and fear_of_rejection for overall health calculation

description.en: You find it very difficult to say 'no' and defend your interests. You often agree to what doesn't suit you, avoid conflicts, and suppress your needs.

en: Start small: practice refusing in safe situations
Use the formula: 'I understand, but this doesn't work for me'
Remember: a polite refusal is not rudeness
Study assertive communication techniques
Work with a psychologist on self-confidence

description.en: You can say 'no' in some situations, but still struggle with boundary defense, especially with close people or authority figures.

en: Identify situations where refusing is harder
Practice ready-made phrases for different scenarios
Work on reducing guilt when refusing
Analyze why these specific people/situations are difficult
Gradually expand your comfort zone in refusals

description.en: You confidently say 'no', defend your interests, and express needs without guilt. You have healthy assertiveness.

en: Continue maintaining healthy assertiveness
Help others develop this skill
Monitor balance between firmness and flexibility
Be an example for others

description.en: You don't tend to sacrifice yourself for others' approval. You can be yourself and don't fear disappointing others.

en: Maintain balance between self-care and caring for others
Continue being authentic
Ensure independence doesn't become isolation

description.en: You sometimes sacrifice your interests for approval, especially in certain relationships or situations. It's important to work on this pattern.

en: Notice moments when you agree against your will
Ask yourself: 'What do I want?' before responding
Practice pausing before automatic 'yes'
Work on self-worth independent of approval
Study the roots of this pattern (childhood, relationships)

description.en: You have a pronounced people-pleasing pattern. You systematically sacrifice yourself for others, lose yourself, and live someone else's life. This requires serious work.

en: IMPORTANT: see a psychologist to work on this pattern
Study roots of codependency and people-pleasing
Start journaling: when and why you agree
Work on self-identification: who are you without others' approval?
Practice small acts of self-care daily
Join a support group or therapy
Read literature: 'Codependent No More' (M. Beattie)

description.en: You don't fear rejection and understand that conflicts and disagreement are normal parts of relationships. You can withstand others' displeasure.

en: Continue cultivating a healthy attitude toward conflicts
Help others cope with fear of rejection
Maintain empathy even with independence

description.en: You experience anxiety at the thought of conflicts or disagreement, but can cope with it. Fear of rejection sometimes influences your decisions.

en: Work on strengthening self-esteem
Remind yourself: conflict ‚â† end of relationship
Practice small acts of disagreement in safe environments
Study anxiety management techniques
Analyze real consequences of conflicts (usually not catastrophic)

description.en: Fear of rejection paralyzes you. You're willing to do anything to avoid conflict or others' displeasure, even to your detriment.

en: CRITICALLY IMPORTANT: work with a psychologist on this fear
Study roots of rejection fear (often in childhood)
Work on anxious attachment style
Practice grounding techniques during panic
Gradual exposure: start with small conflicts
Study CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy)
Read: 'Rewire Your Anxious Brain' (C. Pittman, E. Karle)

description.en: Your personal boundaries are practically nonexistent. You live others' lives, systematically sacrifice yourself, and cannot defend your interests. This leads to burnout, accumulated resentment, and loss of self.

en: IMMEDIATELY see a psychologist
Start working on codependency
Identify one area where you'll set your first boundary
Join a support group
Read literature on boundaries and codependency

description.en: Your boundaries are blurred and inconsistent. You often sacrifice yourself, struggle with refusals, and live considering others' expectations more than your own.
Your boundaries are developing. You already understand their importance and can defend yourself in some situations, but there are still areas for improvement.
You have healthy, clear boundaries. You can say 'no', defend your interests, and don't live for others' expectations. There's room for improvement, but the foundation is strong.
You have exemplary healthy boundaries. You're assertive, take care of yourself, are emotionally autonomous, and know your limits precisely. You're an example for others.
You're a classic people-pleaser. You live for others' approval, fear conflicts, and sacrifice yourself. This emotionally exhausts you and leads to loss of self.

key_issue.en: Fear of being rejected and belief that your value depends on others' approval

en: Working on fear of rejection
Developing self-worth
Practicing saying 'no'

description.en: You're actively working on your boundaries. You understand their importance and are learning to defend yourself. Keep it up!
You have excellent healthy boundaries. You know how to take care of yourself, don't fear conflicts, and live authentically. You can be an example and help others.

exercises.name: 'Pause' Exercise
exercises.description: When asked for something, don't answer immediately. Say: 'I need to think, I'll answer later'. This gives time to assess if you really want to agree.

exercises.name: Boundary Journal
exercises.description: Record situations where you agreed but didn't want to. Analyze: why did you agree? What could you have said instead?

exercises.name: Practicing 'No' in the Mirror
exercises.description: Practice saying 'no' in front of a mirror. Try different phrasings: 'Thank you, but no', 'This doesn't work for me', 'I can't do this'.

exercises.name: Boundary Matrix
exercises.description: Create a list: what's acceptable to you, what's tolerable under certain conditions, what's absolutely unacceptable. This is your boundary map.

exercises.name: Small 'No' Experiment
exercises.description: Start with safe situations: refuse an unwanted newsletter, say 'no' to trying a new dish. Gradually increase difficulty.

reliability.note: Moderate test-retest expected as boundaries can change with therapy

implementation_notes.retake_recommendation: Every 3-6 months to track boundary development progress

warning_message.en: This test does not replace professional psychological help. For serious boundary issues, consult a specialist.
